In order to standardize the gait analysis between visits, we propose conducting the gait analysis protocol at each visit in the following sequence: passive range of motion, sitting, standing up, static posture, and stepping. Each part will be followed by a familiarization session to avoid unexpected muscle contractions while wearing the equipment. The gait analysis protocol will consist of the following components: (I) a 5 m walking trial at self-selected speed in the center of a 10 m walkway, (II) a turn in place on each leg for 15 s, (III) walking at preferred and maximum speeds, and (IV) sitting, standing, and walking repetitions at the rate of one repetition per second. Additionally, we plan on incorporating the following validated scales: 1) the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) to quantify dynamic balance, 2) the modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) to measure spasticity, and 3) the Fugl-Meyer Assessment - Lower Extremity Function (FMA-LE) to measure motor impairment in the lower limbs. Finally, the following inclusion and exclusion criteria will be applied:(Inclusions):-Aged above 40 years old-Chronic stroke that occurred at least six months prior to the inclusion. Understood. Based on your information, your trial seems to be a randomized crossover study. A crossover study, also known as a crossover trial or randomized crossover trial, is a single-blind trial in which each participant receives treatments from each intervention or treatment group in sequence. The advantage of crossover trials is that each participant acts as their own control. As a result, crossover trials generally require fewer participants and less statistical evidence than a parallel group design trial, in this case randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, this comes at the cost of high heterogeneity between each participant as there is no control group. Thus, you may consider using statistical methods such as analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) and analysis of variance (ANOVA) to account for variation between participants .

For the intervention/treatment, in addition to meeting the criteria, potential participants must also be willing to come to the spinal cord injury site for the passive heating treatment three times a week for 12 weeks, be willing to be in the passive heating tank for 30 min, and sign an informed consent and additional study forms. The treatment will be provided by the study team. The intervention will be provided by the study team. The length of time with the passively heated chamber at 44°C temperature is determined based on the participant's response to the intervention and is based on heat tolerance, tolerance levels, blood pressure, heart rate, oxygen saturation, etc. This type of intervention is considered safe but should be closely monitored by healthcare professionals.

The design of the experimental arm of the study combines passive heat therapy and thermal biofeedback using a hot tub at 40 degrees Celsius aimed at raising the core body temperature of the study participants to 38.5 degrees Celsius. This type of passive heat therapy has previously been shown beneficial for cardiovascular disease, as it promotes an exercise-like thermal response without the additional cardiovascular response that would be present during physical exercise. By selecting individuals with higher-level spinal cord injuries, the intervention aims to investigate the potential for a larger cardioprotective effect, taking advantage of the potential for increased vagal nerve activity in the absence of the sympathetic influences of physical exercise. The criteria for the participant group also includes a level transfer being possible with minimal assistance to ensure safety during transfers to the hot tub, and a past engagement in regular bowel and bladder management programs to aid comfort during the intervention's thermal biofeedback. A crossover assignment is a useful option for clinical trials where participants serve as their own control and transition back and forth between interventions and non-interventions. However, if you decide to go with a crossover assignment model, you'll need to modify the blinding protocol. In a crossover clinical trial, participants cannot be blinded because they will necessarily know which intervention they are receiving at any specific time point. Therefore, the best option is to randomly assign participants to the different intervention groups in order to avoid any potential biases in the allocation sequence. For example, in your study, you might consider randomly assigning half of the participants to the blueberry intervention group and the other half to the control group. After a set period of time, all of the participants would then transition to the other group and receive the opposite intervention. This would ensure that both groups receive the same treatments, and the results would be the same as if all participants had been assigned to the same group.

There are several reasons why an ultrasound-guided serratus anterior plane block was chosen for the first study arm. First, rib fractures are responsible for a high portion of acute pain-related admissions to the hospital (Nyholm et al., 2018). Post-surgical pain management is important for these patients to ensure their comfort and improve their recovery. Second, the ultrasound-guided serratus anterior plane block has been shown to be effective in postoperative pain management following chest surgeries (Nyholm et al., 2018; Uezu et al., 2019), which further supports its use for post-surgical pain management. Additionally, the serratus anterior plane block can reduce the need for opioid use and its associated adverse effects (Nyholm et al., 2018; Cheng et al., 2021).

The second study arm is the Test group. In this arm, patients will receive intravenous dexmedetomidine infusion for pain management. They will receive a bolus of 2 mg/kg dexmedetomidine followed by an infusion of 0.7 μg/kg/hr for 48 hours. This arm will be referred to as Group D.

Dexmedetomidine is commonly used in intensive care units to provide sedation and analgesia, and it has been shown to reduce the need for opioids, improve pain control, and reduce opioid-related complications. Given this information, it is a logical second comparator for this study, especially considering that patients in the first arm will receive a combination of levobupivacaine and dexmedetomidine.

model_response: No problem at all. In the diagnostic context, we typically need pilot studies as exploratory trials. They usually occur in phase I. Therefore, I would suggest performing a pilot trial.

For an observational study evaluating the accuracy of a new diagnostic test, the choice of participants is critical. First, consider the target population for which the diagnostic test is intended. In this case, it appears that you are interested in evaluating coronary artery stenosis. Therefore, you will want to focus on individuals who fall into this category.

Patients with significant stenosis (> 90%) detected by coronary computed tomography angiography or coronary angiography, as well as patients with unstable angina, myocardial infarction, uncontrolled high blood pressure, or severe heart failure, should be excluded from the study. Patients with severely calcified vessels (calcified arc) and/or intracoronary thrombus should also be excluded, as should patients with severe valvular heart disease that may require surgical treatment or with a history of congenital heart disease.

Since you're planning to compare the diagnostic accuracy of three diagnostic tests (FFR, UFR, and IVUS), it would be appropriate to have four study arms: (1) invasive gold standard study arm; (2) UFR; (3) IVUS; and (4) FFR.

The second arm of the study should involve the diagnostic test under investigation, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR), as the participant group. The intervention/treatment in this arm of the study should be the new ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) diagnostic technique.

You're welcome! I'm glad I could help. Please keep in mind that the focus of this study should be to accurately assess the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis. Thus, the final decision on the study arms design should also consider factors, such as the safety and effectiveness of the test.

Certainly! Part A is the Escalation cohort and it aims to establish a safe and effective dose of the treatment. This is done by gradually increasing the amount of the treatment that participants receive until a recommended dose (known as the RD, Recommended Dose) is determined. Once the recommended dose has been determined, the trial can proceed to part B, which is the expansion cohort . This cohort will help validate the recommended dose from Part A by testing it against a control group, and demonstrating whether this dose combined with Pembrolizumab has anti-cancer effects that are greater or equivalent than Pembrolizumab alone.

Part B - Expansion will focus on determining the effectiveness of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab. For this arm, we will enroll patients who only have a mutation in Exon 14 of MET (not both Exon 14 and Exon 20) and who also have not received prior therapy for advanced NSCLC. By enrolling these patients, we can assess the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab in patients with Exon 14 MET-mutated NSCLC without any prior treatment.

In Part A - Escalation, the Tepotinib will be administered orally once daily, in addition to intravenous Pembrolizumab, which will be administered every 3 weeks. The dose of Tepotinib will be gradually escalated, with an initial dose of 300 mg per day and a potential escalation up to doses of 500 mg, 750 mg, and 1000 mg per day.

In Part B - Expansion, patients with a confirmed MET exon 14 skipping mutation will receive Tepotinib daily for two weeks, followed by a three-week break. Pembrolizumab immunotherapy will then be given on a 21-day cycle. It is essential to note that the dosage of Tepotinib may be modified following interim analyses to maintain a manageable toxicity profile.

Here's a more detailed description of each study arm in the clinical trial: Group A (early oral feeding postoperative): Enrollment of patients aged 18 years and above who are presenting with perforated duodenal ulcers. After randomization, patients are offered clear fluids, including clear liquids and clear juice, after 6 hours postoperatively. Group B (traditional delayed oral feeding postoperative): Enrollment of patients aged 18 years and above who are presenting with perforated duodenal ulcers. After randomization, patients are advised to withhold oral intake for 72 hours postoperative, then commence from liquids only (i.e., tea, water, sodas, yogurt, pudding, and applesauce) for 48 hours and proceed to solids as tolerated until diet is tolerated. For both groups, all randomized patients will receive a perforated peptic repair. The surgical technique used involves abdominal exploration, closure of perforation with interrupted sutures using non-absorbable sutures (or polydioxanone), oversewing the serosal laceration, intraoperative lavage, and closed ileostomy. The wound is irrigated with bactera-cillin/metronidazole solution and closed in layers with sutures. Postoperative antibiotics will be administered and changed based on the culture sensitivity study. The primary outcome of this clinical trial is to document the association between early oral feeding and patient outcomes, which include hospital days, rehospitalization, 30-day readmission, complications, surgical site infection, and mortality. Secondary outcomes will include patient satisfaction with the type of oral feeding postoperatively, a 15-point pain scale, and a 15-point bowel function patient satisfaction questionnaire.

Group B is the control group with the traditional approach known as delayed oral feeding. In this group, the patients will receive nil per os (NPO), and oral feeding will be resumed 72 hours after perforated peptic ulcer repairs. This approach is more commonly used in practice, and this group serves as a benchmark for comparison with Group A. We will compare how the new approach in Group A compares with the traditional approach in Group B. Group B is designed to follow standard clinical guidelines and serve as a benchmark for the new intervention approach.

The next step would be to perform the sinus lift procedure in the antral area of the extraction socket of the maxillary teeth. This arm is different from the previous arm as the participants in this arm will receive a reduced dose regimen of 43.5 Gy in 23 fractions to the gross disease and intermediate nodes. Non-rapid responders will receive a weekly dose of paclitaxel until the end of concurrent chemoradiation. The chemotherapy regimen will be paclitaxel 120 mg/m2 week 1, 240 mg/m2 week 2, 120 mg/m2 weeks 3-6, and 90 mg/m2 weeks 7-12. The intervention/treatment for this arm is also external beam radiation to the head and neck. The addition of chemotherapy to this arm will allow us to assess the impact of the combination of a reduced dose of radiotherapy and chemotherapy on non-rapid responders. By comparing this arm to the first arm, we can evaluate the impact of chemotherapy in this specific subgroup. We can compare the effectiveness and safety of fixed versus free combination for this lower dose of Perindopril. After the initial 2 months, all patients should continue to receive the same combination as during the initial 2 months (Perindopril 5 mg / Indapamide 1.25 mg / Amlodipine 5 mg for the experimental arm and the free combination of Perindopril 4 mg /Indapamide 1.25 mg plus Amlodipine 5 mg for the active comparator arm). The purpose of the trial is to assess the benefits and risks of embolization as an adjuvant to surgical decompression, and thus, we need to include both the surgery-only and embolization-only groups.

In the second arm, patients with chronic subdural hematomas undergo surgical treatment for them and receive MMA embolization post-surgery. This arm will be referred to as Arm 2 - Surgery + Embolization.

The purpose of this arm is to determine whether MMA embolization immediately after surgical treatment could further reduce recurrent hematoma and improve overall outcomes. This is the key study arm and the focus of the study is on this arm and its comparison to the primary study's arm.

The third study arm entails patients who undergo surgery but don't receive MMA embolization, and also receive MMA embolization for cSDH recurrence within 72 hours after surgery. This arm, which will be referred to as Arm 3 - Surgery - S/P MMA embolization, will allow us to compare the outcomes in patients with Arm 2 and Arm 1 and see whether early embolization (<72 hours post-surgery) is more effective in reducing recurrences than delayed embolization (after failure of conservative treatment).

The significance of having this arm is to show the efficacy of MMA embolization alone in treating subacute or recurrent chronic subdural hematomas. By comparing the outcomes in this group with those in the other arms, we can provide insights on the effectiveness of MMA embolization as a standalone treatment.

The final study arm is similar to the third study arm, but this group includes patients who refuse both surgery and MMA embolization. Instead, they will receive conservative medical management. This arm will be referred to as Arm 4 - No surgery - Embolization declined.

The purpose of including this arm is to capture and document a different group of patients not opting for either surgical or embolization treatment, and their subsequent status. This way, a comparison can be made in the final analysis between Arms 3 and 4 and the following question can be answered - is it better to consider embolization as a standalone treatment approach compared to doing nothing? Furthermore, this will help identify room for improvement in the study protocols and study recruitment.

We will name the study arms the active arm and the placebo arm. In the active arm, participants will receive real, non-invasive vagus nerve stimulation treatment, while in the placebo arm, participants will receive a placebo vagus nerve stimulation treatment.

For the Experimental arm, the participant group/arm will consist of participants who will receive non-invasive auricular vagus stimulation. The intervention/treatment involves using a non-invasive device to stimulate the auricular branch of the vagus nerve. Several experimental, preclinical and clinical studies have demonstrated that this type of electrical stimulation on the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (tVNS) can increase pain threshold and decrease hyperalgesia. One of the proposed mechanism underlying this effect of tVNS on pain is the inhibition of the sympathetic activity. In animal models of neuropathic pain, stimulating the auricular branch of the vagus nerve suppresses the expression of neuropeptide Y (which is involved in sympathetic activity), inflammatory pain mediators and proinflammatory cytokine release, thereby leading to a reduction in allodynia. Interestingly, both vagus nerve stimulation and electrical stimulation of the ear have been shown to decrease plasma norepinephrine, the neurotransmitter mostly responsible for the sympathetic activity, in conscious patients. Therefore, a speculated mechanism behind this phenomenon is the influence of electrical stimulation of the ear on the neurotransmitters of the neuroimmune system, namely, norepinephrine, and thereby inducing an anti-inflammatory effect. Interestingly, electrical ear stimulation by acupuncture (i.e., electroacupuncture), and by a device called Vital Stim, which has electrodes on the ears and nose (also called VNS Therapy or Nerivio), is being used in some medical centers for several conditions, including chronic pain, and shows positive results.

For the Placebo Comparator arm, the participant group/arm should consist of participants who will receive a placebo intervention. The intervention/treatment for this arm will involve using a non-invasive device that does not stimulate the vagus nerve.

The purpose of including a Placebo Comparator arm in this study is to enable us to evaluate the effect of the vagus nerve stimulation itself. By comparing the results of this arm to those of the Experimental arm, we can determine whether the changes observed are due to the stimulation of the vagus nerve, or to placebo effects.

Certainly! The full study arms are as follows: Experimental arm: Participants will receive both non-invasive auricular vagus stimulation, and aerobic exercise. The device was described as “comfortable to wear and simple to use”. Placebo Comparator arm: Participants will receive both the placebo non-invasive device and aerobic exercise. The authors of the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System (ABAS-3) have developed an adaptation of their assessment battery so that it can be used by individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities with a limited repertoire of verbal behaviors and who are capable of making some response to a core vocabulary containing 20 stimuli. The authors have identified a set of guidelines to aid in using the instrument with this population. The authors suggest that the adult version of the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System (ABAS-3) can be used with individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities who are limited in their verbal output when the test administration follows a structured, step-by-step protocol. This protocol involves the use of a core vocabulary containing only the stimuli relevant to the individual's evaluation and the use of augmentative strategies, including gestures, pictured instructions, facial expressions, and modeling.

Of course. In the first intervention arm, the DC cardioversion phase, a non-defibrillatory version of the ACUTAS DC cardioverter (ACU Medical, USA) will be delivered for 50–100 s for a maximum of five times for electrical cardioversion and four attempts using the transthoracic approach. Once the DC conversion is stable, the patient will receive guided catheter ablation to block four pulmonary veins (PVs). Each vein will be ablated with a single radiofrequency (RF) or cryoballoon (CB) catheter in a nonoverlapping sequence.

Sure! For the second study arm, known as the sham comparator arm, patients will undergo an electrocardiogram (ECG) without active catheter manipulation in the left atrium. They will not have PVI performed, nor will they undergo ablation of any kind. However, two femoral sheaths will be inserted at the groin area, and an implantable loop recorder will be inserted in the pre-pectoral area with local anesthetic at least one week before randomization. This study arm aims to control for the potential placebo effect of the procedure such as sedation or contact with medical staff. The main endpoint in this study will be the same as described for the active comparator arm, although there will be no DC cardioversion performed. Any questions or modifications before we move on to the primary and secondary measures?

Absolutely. DC cardioversion will be performed as per the active comparator arm. Intermittent phrenic nerve pacing will be used to create left ventricular pacing artifact, which will be indistinguishable from PVI signals and create a simulation of pulmonary vein isolation. It is important to note that this is a purely electrical simulation without the physical creation of ablation lesions, distinguishing it from the active comparator arm. Moreover, this simulation of PVI is consistent with sham procedures in other arrhythmias and ablation trials. Patients will be randomized to a different femoral vein sheath size of 3F and 7Fr in the sham arm in order to distinguish the sheaths that were inserted in all patients prior to randomization. Is there anything else I can add or modify for this arm?

The number of interviews conducted for qualitative research depends on several factors, including the study's objective, research question, data analysis method, and saturation level. Qualitative experts usually recommend the sample size to be small, typically between 10 and 15 participants . The goal for qualitative studies is to achieve theoretical saturation, which means that no new themes or patterns emerge from the data after interviews with subsequent participants. To attain saturation, it is generally recommended that an initial 5 to 50 participants will likely reveal the most relevant themes, while collecting data from an additional 5–10 individuals may help identify less common concepts, scenarios, or experiences, depending on the sample and data collection strategy . However, the exact number of interviews required can vary from person to person, depending on the characteristics of the population and the research question. By the time the 10th or 15th participant is interviewed, most key themes should be identified and refined.

It is important to consider that tooth preparation for a crown can result in large amounts of tooth structure removal and may cause weakness in the tooth, especially in areas of remaining wall compromise. The removal of the pulp can leave the tooth susceptible to fracture, so it is usually recommended to make the preparation marginless (supragingival or nonsubgingival) to promote greater retention of existing tooth structure. Although supragingival margin is prefered because of the better ability in the removal of plaque around the final restoration without the use of surgical microscopes or magnifying glasses and easier access to the cervical margins of most tooth preparations, nonsubgingival margin can be prefered in deep cavities and tooth preparation. In these cases, subgingival cavities have already compromised the wall beneath the cavity itself, therefore, a subgingival margin elevation is needed for tooth strength . Resin-modified glass ionomer cements, commonly referred to as RMGI, are a type of light-cured materials that combine the properties of traditional glass ionomers such as fluoride release, radiopacity, and high bond strength, with those of resin-based composites, which are tooth-colored, adhesive, and non-corrosive to the oral environment (1). Glass ionomers are known for their biocompatibility and antibacterial properties, but they have been limited in use due to handling difficulties, low wear resistance, and low mechanical strength (2). The introduction of RMGI resolves some of the handling difficulties of conventional glass ionomers, while still providing high fluoride release and antimicrobial ability, along with improved mechanical properties, such as tensile strength.
